column1: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are medicines that work by reducing the amount of stomach acid made by glands in the lining of your stomach.
Proton pump inhibitors are used to: - Relieve symptoms of acid reflux, or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
This is a condition in which food or liquid moves up from the stomach to the esophagus (the tube from the mouth to the stomach).

- Omeprazole (Prilosec), also available over-the-counter (without a prescription) - Esomeprazole (Nexium) - Lansoprazole (Prevacid) - Rabeprazole (AcipHex) - Pantoprazole (Protonix) - Dexlansoprazole (Dexilant) - Zegerid (omeprazole with sodium bicarbonate)
Talk to your doctor if you find you have to take these medicines on most days.
Some people who have acid reflux may need to take PPIs every day.
Or your doctor may ask you to take these drugs for 8 weeks.
PPIs may change the way certain drugs work, including some anti-seizure medicines and blood thinners such as warfarin or clopidogrel (Plavix).
